parts:
Examine the attached HTML file. This file forms the template I wish to use for my website.

I have an existing wordpress website at https://sgmathtuition.com

My aim is to change the appearance of the sgmathtuition.com website to match the HTML template. 

I am prepared to manually re-enter the data and information on the existing sgmathtuition.com website, including important blog postings. 

All the design elements of the HTML template such as the sticky header, light/dark toggle, whatsapp icon, and all CSS effects, will be retained. In other words, it will be a theme overhaul to match the look and feel of the HTML template.

The updated sgmathtuition.com website will still allow addition of blog posts and also addition of sections to the main landing page. I am willing to take a "low-level" approach when it comes to addition of sections to the landing page -- that is, direct editing of HTML code and manual uploading of images.

Examine how I can achieve the above aims.
Make sure to include citeturn0file0 in your response to cite this file.

thoughts.content:
I see the user wants to transform their provided HTML template into a custom WordPress theme, making sure to retain current content, include a blog, and edit static and landing page sections manually.  

I'll need to develop the theme from scratch or build on an existing base, with some key steps like setting up a local environment for development, breaking the template into required WordPress parts (e.g., header.php, footer.php), and ensuring proper script and style management in the functions file. That’s a good starting point for creating a custom theme.

To help the user, creating a custom WordPress theme from their HTML template is an option. Based on the user’s skills (technical background and comfort with editing), a minimal child theme based on Twenty Twenty-Four or _s would work well. It’s important to ensure a smooth process by exporting the content beforehand and using a staging environment to avoid downtime. I'll also cover key tasks like creating sticky headers, light/dark themes, WhatsApp integration, and handling blog posts efficiently within the new theme structure.

I’m thinking of laying this out clearly for the user. First, I'll compare creating a custom theme vs using a page builder. My recommendation includes setting up a local dev environment, converting the template to a theme, and creating necessary theme files like header.php, footer.php, and enqueueing scripts. 

I'll also cover adding features like a dark/light toggle, WhatsApp button, and post templates. Finally, I’ll walk through content migration, testing, and deployment with backup precautions.

thoughts.content: To guide the user, first, I'll explain the differences between building a custom theme and using a page builder. I'll recommend starting with a staging environment, then converting their template into a WordPress theme. I'll break down the steps like setting up the dev environment, creating the theme folder, adding necessary files like functions.php, and adding features like a nav menu, light/dark toggle, and WhatsApp button. I'll also go over content migration, deployment, and maintenance with security considerations.

parts:
Below is a practical, code-level roadmap for turning the uploaded HTML template into a fully-functional WordPress theme that replaces (and modernises) **sgmathtuition.com** while preserving all your existing content and future blogging capability. --- ## 1 Overall strategy | Option | Pros | Cons | Recommendation for you | |--------|------|------|------------------------| | **Classic “PHP” child theme** (based on Twenty-Twenty-Four or \_s) | · Fast to build – drop HTML into header.php / footer.php
· Works with Classic Editor or Gutenberg
· Familiar to devs since WP 3.x | · More manual markup editing each time WordPress changes
· Cannot tap newest Full-Site-Editing (FSE) features | Viable, but gives up new block-theme tools | | **Block theme (FSE) built from template** | · Uses WordPress ≥6.5 block system, Font Library, Interactivity API – future-proof citeturn0search0
· Drag-and-drop editing of any template part in Site Editor
· Lets you package sections as reusable patterns, so you can insert them into the landing page without touching code | · Slightly steeper learning curve
· Requires WordPress 6.5+ | **Best long-term choice** – keeps your low-level control yet lets non-tech staff edit content safely | *Below I outline the block-theme path. If you prefer the classic approach, the same file breakdown applies – just ignore theme.json and edit PHP directly.* --- ## 2 Set up a safe workspace 1. **Spin up a local or staging clone** – e.g. `wp-env`, Local WP, or an inexpensive sub-domain. 2. **Export** posts & pages from production (`Tools → Export`) or rely on the fact you’ll re-enter data manually. 3. **Upgrade WordPress to ≥ 6.5** (current LTS) so you have Font Library, Interactivity API, Block Bindings, etc.citeturn0search1 4. Keep *all* work under version control (`git`) and deploy by pushing to GitHub → GitHub Actions → SFTP/rsync. --- ## 3 Bootstrapping the theme folder ``` sgmt-template/ ├── theme.json ├── style.css (Tiny; only theme header + variables) ├── functions.php (enqueue extras, register menus) ├── parts/ │ ├── header.html │ ├── footer.html │ ├── whatsapp.html │ └── head-dark-toggle.html ├── templates/ │ ├── index.html (blog index) │ ├── single.html (blog post) │ └── front-page.html (landing page) ├── assets/ │ ├── css/template.css (full CSS from uploaded file) │ └── js/template.js (hamburger, dark-mode, WhatsApp) └── screenshot.png ``` ### 3.1 theme.json (minimal starter) ```jsonc { "$schema": "https://schemas.wp.org/trunk/theme.json", "version": 3, "settings": { "color": { "palette": [], "gradients": [] }, "custom": { "lightbg": "#f5f6fa", "darkbg": "#23272f" } }, "styles": { "color": { "background": "var(--wp--custom--lightbg)" } }, "templateParts": [ { "name": "header", "title": "Header", "area": "header" }, { "name": "footer", "title": "Footer", "area": "footer" } ] } ``` This tells WordPress you are an FSE theme, registers header/footer parts, and lets the Site Editor load them. ### 3.2 functions.php ```php __( 'Primary Menu', 'sgmt' ), ] ); ?> ``` --- ## 4 Slice the uploaded HTML into block parts *File reference: uploaded template* citeturn0file0 ### 4.1 `parts/header.html` Replace `
` in the template by its Gutenberg block equivalent: ```html
``` *Why raw HTML block?* The Site Editor can still select and reposition it, but you keep your exact CSS/JS hook-ups. ### 4.2 `parts/footer.html` Use a **Group** block wrapping an **HTML** block that pastes your `
` markup; dynamic year via ``. ### 4.3 Navigation In the WP admin, create a “Primary” menu matching the list items in the template. Gutenberg’s Navigation block will render it; the CSS you shipped already styles `.nav`, `.dropdown`, etc. If you need the exact caret behaviour, create a small **JavaScript** snippet (`template.js`) that appends the `▾` to `li > button` nodes generated by WordPress. --- ## 5 Blog templates 1. **index.html** – Use **Query Loop** block with your preferred card design. 2. **single.html** – Add **Post Content**, **Post Author**, etc., below the sticky header. 3. **archives**: For category pages create `archive.html` if needed. The Interactivity API in WP 6.5 lets your dark-mode toggle or hamburger stay outside the loop; it will not break when WordPress adds more blocks.citeturn0search2 --- ## 6 Landing page sections Because you are happy to “edit HTML directly”: 1. **Create patterns**: Each section from the template (“Our Mission”, “What We Offer” …) is saved as a **reusable pattern** in `/patterns/*.html`. 2. In **front-page.html** you simply insert: ```html ``` Now adding/removing a section = delete the pattern call; no database risk. --- ## 7 WhatsApp floating button *Low-code approach* – include `` block in `parts/whatsapp.html`: ```html ``` Then append the event-handler and **pulse** animation already present in `template.js`. --- ## 8 Dark / light mode persistence Your uploaded script already writes to `localStorage`. Wrap the JS in a IIFE loaded by `wp_enqueue_script`, **or** (modern way) register it as an Interactivity API directive so that it re-hydrates instantly when a visitor changes theme. --- ## 9 Migrating content | Task | Tool | |------|------| | Export existing posts from old site | `Tools → Export` (XML) | | Import into new site | `Tools → Import → WordPress` | | Re-assign featured images | Media Library, bulk select, *Set featured image* | | Recreate categories / tags | They come over via WXR; just rename if needed | Because you may manually re-enter, you can ignore the export step, but keep the old site live until search engines re-index. --- ## 10 Staging ➜ Production 1. **Backup** old site (database + wp-content). 2. Deploy new theme to `/wp-content/themes/sgmt-template`. 3. Activate it in **Appearance → Themes**; verify pages. 4. Flush caches + regenerate critical CSS (if using a cache plugin). --- ## 11 Maintenance & future proofing * **CSS isolation** – all template styles live in `assets/css`; future WordPress updates won’t overwrite them. * **Updates** – When WP 6.6 arrives, test locally; block themes rarely break. * **Security** – Stick to 3rd-party plugins only for SEO (Yoast/Rank Math), caching, spam blocking. --- ### Final sanity check | Requirement | Addressed? | |-------------|------------| | Sticky header | Yes – header part persists across templates | | Light / dark toggle | Template JS + optional Interactivity API rewrite | | WhatsApp button | HTML block + CSS/JS remains intact | | CSS effects unchanged | Stylesheet copied verbatim | | Blog capability | index.html + single.html (Query Loop) | | Ability to add landing-page sections | Reusable patterns or direct HTML edit | You now have a lean, future-proof WordPress theme whose **look-and-feel is pixel-perfect to your HTML template** while keeping the comfort of WP’s editor and blogging engine.
